gurmukhi: ihq jwn qws htikE kunwr ]nhI lok qRws bu`lY Bqwr ]qb kuVI nwr icq ros Twn ]sMBl nryS qn khI Awn ]170]
transliteration: Hit Jaan Taas Hatkio Kounaar|| Nahilok Traas Bullai Bhataar|| Tab Kudinaar Chit Ros Thaan|| Sanbhal Daresh Tan Kahi Aan|| 170||
translation: He rebuked his wife, realizing her welfare and because of the fear of public discussion, the husband kept silent; on this, that woman got enraged and going before the king of the town of Sambhal, she related the whole episode.170.

gurmukhi: pUjMq dyvy dIny idKwie ]iqh ghw kop kir sUdR rwie ]gih qwih AiDk dInI sjwie ]kY hnq qoh kY jp n mwie ]171]
transliteration: Poojant Deve Deeno Dikhaae|| Tih Gadaa Kop Kar(i) Soodra Raae|| Gadh Taah(i) Adhik Deenisajaae|| Kai Banat Toh Kai Jap Na Maae||171||
translation: She showed the worshipping Brahmin to the king and the Shudra king getting infuriated, arrested him and giving him the hard punishment, the king said, “I shall kill you, or you abandon the worship of the goddess.”171.

gurmukhi: nhI hnq qoh idj khI Awj ]nhI bor bwr mo pUj swj ]kY qjhu syv dyvI pRcMf ]nhI krq Awj qoko duKMf ]172]
transliteration: Nahi Banat Toh Dij Jahiaaj|| Nahi Bor Baar Mo Pooj Saaj|| Kai Tajoh Sev Deviprachanndd|| Nahikarat Aaj Toko Doukhand||172||
translation: “O Brahmin ! throw away this material of worship in the water, otherwise I shall kill you today; abandon the worship of the goddess, otherwise I shall chop you into two parts.”172.
Spech of the Brahmin addressed to the king :

gurmukhi: kIjY duKMf nhI qjo syv ]sun lyhu swcu quh kho dyv ]ikau n hoih tUk qn ky hjwr ]nhI qjo pwie dyvI audwr ]173]
transliteration: Kijai Doukhanndnahitajo Sev|| Soun Leh(u) Saach(u) Tuh Kaho Dev|| Kio Na Hoh(i) Took Tan Ke Hajaar|| Nahitajo Paae Deviudaar||173
translation: “O king ! I am telling you the truth; you may cut me into two parts, but I cannot leave the worship of the without hesitation, I shall not leave the feet of the goddess.”173.

gurmukhi: sun BXo bYx SUdr su kRu`D ]jxu jutXo Awix mkrwC ju`D ]doaU diRg skRuD sRonq cucwn ]jn kwl qwih dInI inSwn ]174]
transliteration: Soun Bhayo Bain Shoodar Su Kruddh|| Jad(u) Joutyo Aan(i) Makraachh Juddh|| Dooo Drig Skrudh Sronat Chouchaan|| Jan Kaal Taah(i) Deeninishaan||174||
translation: Hearing these words, the Shudra king fell upon the Brahmin like the demon Makraksha on the enemy; the blood gushed up from both the eyes of the Yama-like king.174.

gurmukhi: Aiq grb mUV BiR`qn bulwie ]au`cry bYx ieh hxo jwie ]lY gey qws dRohI durMq ]jh sMBR suB dyvl suBMq ]175]
transliteration: At(i) Gadab Moond Bhrittan Bulaae|| Ouchcdare Bain Eh Hano Jaae|| Lai Gad Taas Drohidurant|| Jah Sanbhra Soubh Deval Soubhant||175||
translation: That foolish king called his servants and said, “Kill this Brahmin.” Those tyrants took him to the temple of the goddess.175.

gurmukhi: iqh bwD AwNK muskY cVwie ]kr lIn kwF As ko ncwie ]jb lgy dyn iqh qyg qwn ]qb kIXo kwl ko ibDR iDAwn ]176]
transliteration: Tih Baadh Aankh Mouskai Chadhaae|| Kar Leen Kaadh As Ko Nachaae|| Jah Lage Den Tih Teg Taan|| Tab Keeyo Kaal Ko Bipra Dhiaan||176||
translation: Tying the bandage before his eyes and tying his hands, they took out the glistening sword; when they were about to strike the blow with the sword, then that Brahmin remembered KAL (death).176.

gurmukhi: jb kIXo icq mo ibpR iDAwn ]iqh dIn drs qb kwl Awn ]nhI kro icMq icq mwNiJ eyk ]qv hyq S`qRu hin hY Anyk ]177]
transliteration: Jab Keeyo Chit Mo Bipra Dhiaan|| Tih Deen Daras Tab Kaal Aan|| Nahi Daro Chint Chit Maanjh(i) Ek|| Tav Het Shattru Han(i) Hai Anek||177||
translation: When the Brahmin mediated on KAL (death), then he appeared before him and said, “Do not worry in your mind, I shall kill many enemies for your sake.”177.

gurmukhi: qb prI SUMk Borh mJwr ]aupijE Awn klkI vqwr ]qwV pRmwnu krIAs auqMg ]qr k`C su v`C qwjI surMg ]178]
transliteration: Tah Parishoonk Bhorah Majhaar|| Oupjio Aan Kalkivataar|| Taad Pramaan(u) Dareeas Outan|| Tar Kachchh Su Vachchh Taajisuran||178||
translation: Then a dreadful sound was heard from the basement of the temple and Kalki incarnation manifested Himself; he was long like the palm tree; He had bedecked His waist with quiver and he was riding on a beautiful horse.178.

gurmukhi: v`jy nwd surMgI D`kw GorIAw ]n`cy jwx iPrMgI v`jy GuMGrU ]
transliteration: Vajje Naad Suranidhakkaa Ghoreeaa|| Nachche Jaan Phiranivajje Ghounghroo||
translation: There was a loud sound and the heroic spirits began to dance tying small bells round the ankles;

gurmukhi: gdw qiRsUl inKMgI JUln bYrKwN ]swvx jwx aumMgI Gtw frwvxI ]179]
transliteration: Gadaa Trisool Nikhani Jhoolan Bairkhaan|| Saavan Jaan Oumanighataa Daraavanee||179||
translation: The maces, tridents, quivers and lances swung and waved like the dark clouds of Sawan.179.
